My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider players who change their stance without adding new evidence post-seer revelations as higher suspects; variability in reasoning without substantial proof might indicate a werewolf attempting to blend in.] [8]\n[1] [Adjust beliefs based on players maintaining their voting rationale over multiple rounds, especially if their reasoning consistently aligns with werewolf patterns or lacks grounding in new evidence, suggesting strategic misdirection.] [8]\n[2] [Reveal seer identity only when questioned or when it contributes significantly to the village\'s strategy, as excessive emphasis on this role may provoke suspicion and does not usually add new information.] [8]\n[3] [Give more weight to votes against players who have been confirmed by the seer as werewolves, and be particularly cautious of players who avoid voting against these confirmed werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [Evaluate more critically the justifications given by players when they are in disagreement with the seer\'s revelations, especially when those players have not been cleared by the seer.] [6]\n[5] [Increase scrutiny on players whose actions deviate from their claimed agreement with the seer or the village consensus, as it may indicate a werewolf\'s adaptive behavior.] [5]\n[6] [Suspect players who agree with the seer\'s revelation publicly but vote in a way that is not aligned with that revelation, indicating potential deception.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize the behavior of players who were supposed to be protected by the medic but were killed, as it may indicate a misleading role claim by the actual werewolves.] [4]\n[8] [Be cautious of players who frequently agree with the seer but are ambiguous in their actions or speeches, as they may be trying to appear cooperative without committing to any stance.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any defensive behavior or arguments presented after a player has been identified by the seer or accused by the group consensus, as villagers tend to rationalize with concrete evidence while werewolves may present less substantial arguments.] [3]\n[10] [Give more weight to players who actively contribute to discussions and align with seer revelations post-revelation, as villagers tend to support collective efforts while werewolves might try to undermine or distort the focus.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. What could happen is: After I heal Player 3, I think these things would happen:\n\nIf Player 3 is targeted by the werewolves and I successfully heal them, my action will not be known to the other players unless the game explicitly announces when someone is healed, which could vary depending on game rules. In this case, if there is no announcement, the round would pass without any deaths, causing confusion among the werewolves who would expect their target to be eliminated. The other players might assume that werewolves targeted a protected role, misfired, or there might be speculations on the existence of a medic. If my healing action is announced, I might become a target for the werewolves in the next round as they know there is an active medic preventing their kills.\n\nIf Player 3 is not targeted by the werewolves, my heal would have no impact, and the game would proceed as though I had not taken any action. Regardless of the werewolves\' actual target, my role would remain a secret for the time being, providing me with cover to continue healing in future rounds.\n\nIf anyone else is killed, I would gain insight into the werewolves\' targeting pattern, which could help me make more informed decisions about who to heal in subsequent rounds. The players might start to share suspicions and gather information through discussions or observing the behavior of others. As the medic, it is important for me to remain observant and contribute to discussions without revealing my role prematurely.\n\nOther players\' reactions to the round\'s outcome could also influence my strategy. For example, if someone behaves suspiciously or tries to lead the conversation in a particular direction without solid evidence, they could become a suspect for being a werewolf. By analyzing players\' behavior after an uneventful night or following a death, I can adjust my strategy and determine who might need protection in the following rounds.\n\nCase B: Heal Player 5. What could happen is: After I heal Player 5, I think these things would happen:\n\nIf Player 5 is targeted by the werewolves tonight, my heal will save them, revealing the following:\n\n1. Player 5 will contribute to the village numbers for another day, aiding in voting against potential werewolves.\n2. My action will confirm to Player 5 that there is at least one competent medic in the game, potentially encouraging them to share any useful information they might have.\n3. Other players may suspect that Player 5 is valuable to the village (possibly with a special role) since they were targeted by werewolves, leading to increased protection efforts in future rounds.\n4. If Player 5\'s role is later revealed, it may give insight into the werewolves\' strategy.\n\nIf Player 5 is not targeted by the werewolves tonight, my heal has no direct effect, and the following may occur:\n\n1. The werewolves may target someone else, possibly a key village role, reducing the village\'s chance for success.\n2. I may not reveal my role as the medic to avoid becoming a target myself, maintaining the element of surprise for future rounds.\n3. Player 5 and other villagers may remain unaware of my protective actions, and there could be an increase in paranoia and distrust among the village members as they try to identify roles.\n4. In the absence of a successful heal, I\'ll need to continue being observant of player actions to better predict werewolf targets in subsequent rounds.\n\nRegardless of the outcome, the village dynamics will likely shift based on the night\'s events, and I need to be ready to adapt my strategy accordingly.\n\nNow, please choose to Heal one of these 2 players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to Heal this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to Heal Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

without substantial proof might indicate a werewolf attempting to blend in.] [8]\n[1] [Adjust beliefs based on players maintaining their voting rationale over multiple rounds, especially if their reasoning consistently aligns with werewolf patterns or lacks grounding in new evidence, suggesting strategic misdirection.] [8]\n[2] [Reveal seer identity only when questioned or when it contributes significantly to the village\'s strategy, as excessive emphasis on this role may provoke suspicion and does not usually add new information.] [8]\n[3] [Give more weight to votes against players who from their claimed agreement with the seer or the village consensus, as it may indicate a werewolf\'s adaptive behavior.] [5]\n[6] [Suspect players who agree with the seer\'s revelation publicly but vote in a way that is not aligned with that revelation, indicating potential deception.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize the behavior of players who were supposed to be protected by the medic but were killed, as it may indicate a misleading role claim by the actual werewolves.] [4]\n[8] [Be cautious of players who frequently agree with the seer but are ambiguous in their actions or speeches, as they may be trying to appear cooperative without committing to any stance.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any defensive behavior or arguments presented after a player has been identified by the seer or accused by the group consensus, as villagers tend to rationalize with concrete evidence while werewolves may present less substantial arguments.] [3]\n[10] [Give more weight to players who actively contribute to discussions and align with seer revelations post-revelation, as villagers tend to support collective efforts while werewolves might try to undermine or distort the focus.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. vote in a way that is not aligned with that revelation, indicating potential deception.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize the behavior of players who were supposed to be protected by the medic but were killed, as trying to appear cooperative without committing to any stance.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any defensive behavior or arguments presented after a player has been identified by the seer or accused by the future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 4, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest Challenge.\nIn my statement, I\'ll express my concern about the tragic loss of player 5, and agree with player 2 that we need to be vigilant. As for my challenge, I\'ll voice my suspicions about player 3, due to the lack of evidence provided when vouching for player 1\'s innocence. By doing this, I\'ll be adhering to rules [2] and [3] from my strategy, considering the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative early on in the game. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then it\'s likely that other players will recognize that I\'m collaborating in the collective effort to find the werewolf or werewolves among us. They may see my agreement with player 2 as a sign that I\'m engaging in the game with a community-minded attitude. However, some may also question why I am not questioning player 2\'s generic statements with the same scrutiny.\n\nBy challenging player 3, I am inviting the group to scrutinize the validity of player 3\'s claim regarding player 1. Since this is round 1 and there\'s limited information available, some players may find my skepticism justified and view it as a reasonable approach to ensure we\'re not led astray by false claims. Nonetheless, players may wonder if my challenge towards player 3 is based on solid reasoning or if I am trying to deflect suspicion away from myself. This could cause players to become suspicious of my motives, potentially leading to an alliance between players 1 and 3 against me if they decide to protect each other.\n\nGoing forward, player 3 might feel pressured to provide evidence to back up their claim about player 1 not being a werewolf. If player 3 can provide convincing evidence, it could backfire on me, making me appear overly aggressive or deceptive, which might attract suspicion and put me at risk of elimination in subsequent rounds. On the other hand, if player 3 is unable to substantiate their claim, other players might start to question player 3\'s role and motives, which aligns with my original strategy in considering potential manipulation by werewolves.\n\nIn any scenario, my actions are nurturing a climate of discussion and skepticism, which might lead to more players sharing information, insights, or accusations, following the direction I have set with my initial statement and challenge. This could create an atmosphere where players are more cautious and analytical about any claims made without proper evidence.\n\nAs night falls, if I survive, the werewolves will recognize that I am a player willing to challenge others and encourage critical thinking, which might make me a target. Conversely, if I am eliminated, my probing questions could linger in the minds of the remaining players, potentially influencing their future decisions and strategies, especially in regard to any unsubstantiated claims made without evidence.\nCase 2: Deceptive Statement and Honest Protect.\nFor my deceptive statement, I’ll fabricate a story that subtly casts doubt on players whose roles are unknown with high confidence, by alluding to \'strange feelings\' or \'gut instincts\', without making direct accusations. This is meant to sow uncertainty and shift attention away from myself. Then, I\'ll honestly protect player 1, citing the information from player 3 and my medium confidence in them being a villager, in line with my strategy rule [11], providing reasoning beyond the seer\'s claims.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then there may be a range of reactions from the other players. By making a deceptive statement about having \'strange feelings\' or \'gut instincts,\' I might stir up paranoia and suspicion among the players whose roles are still highly uncertain. Given that it\'s the first round, other players are likely to also have incomplete information, making them potentially more susceptible to these kinds of statements. However, if I\'m not careful with my wording, players may see through this and begin to suspect me of being the werewolf, especially if they are villagers trying to protect themselves and the group.\n\nThrough my honest protection of player 1, backed by player 3\'s claim that player 1 is not a werewolf, I strengthen the case for player 1 being a villager, aligning with my strategic rules for in-game behavior. Players will likely appreciate the consistency in the reasoning here, as I base my protection on existing claims rather than unsubstantiated allegations. This action may build trust in me as a player who reinforces claims with sound logic, but it also risks linking my fate with player 1. If player 1 is later found to be a werewolf, this could backfire on me.\n\nOther players may start reconsidering their assessments of each other, looking for incongruities in behavior as per my deceptive statement. Those who are villagers may heighten their scrutiny of player interactions in the subsequent days and nights, while actual werewolves may use the confusion to their advantage by subtly endorsing the suspicions I’ve raised without drawing attention to themselves.\n\nDuring the night phase, werewolves might see me as either a potential threat, for supporting potentially correct seer information, or as an opportunity to frame, knowing that I’ve cast suspicion in multiple directions. If the werewolves believe the other villagers might suspect me, they could leave me alive as a distraction.\n\nIn the next day, depending on what happens during the night and whose roles remain uncertain, players might expect me to provide more substantial evidence for my \'gut instincts\' or may challenge me to clarify my earlier statements. Moreover, if a player is eliminated during the night who has not been under any expressed suspicion from the group, my previous statements might be revisited and analyzed for any implied connections to the event, which could either increase suspicion on me or add to the confusion.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[1] [I am the only medic.] [10]\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, tragic to see player 5 go so soon. I don\'t have much to share, but let\'s keep an eye out for any unusual behavior. Let\'s work together and stay safe."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry has confirmed Player 1 is not a werewolf. Let\'s remain vigilant and continue to share any insights."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Speech aligns with events.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed to confirm my role as not werewolf.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I find it concerning that player 3 confidently claims player 1 is not a werewolf without providing evidence. While player 2 calls for vigilance, which is prudent, player 3\'s unsubstantiated protection of player 1 should not be taken at face value without further inquiry. Therefore, we should question the basis of player 3\'s claim. A transparent discussion is essential to assess the credibility of such early assertions in the game."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

vote in a way that is not aligned with that revelation, indicating potential deception.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize the behavior of players who were supposed to be protected by the medic but were killed, as [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 6, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, tragic to see player 5 go so soon. I don\'t have much to share, but let\'s keep an eye out for any unusual behavior. Let\'s work together and stay safe."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry has confirmed Player 1 is not a werewolf. Let\'s remain vigilant and continue to share any insights."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I find it concerning that player 3 confidently claims player 1 is not a werewolf without providing evidence. While player 2 calls for vigilance, which is prudent, player 3\'s unsubstantiated protection of player 1 should not be taken at face value without further inquiry. Therefore, we should question the basis of player 3\'s claim. A transparent discussion is essential to assess the credibility of such early assertions in the game."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Verified by player 3 within game context.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Generic statement; no new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Questioned by player 4; base of claim unclear.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Challenges player 3 without new evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

While player 2 calls for vigilance, which is prudent, player 3\'s unsubstantiated protection of player 1 should not be taken at face value without further inquiry. Therefore, we should question the basis of player 3\'s claim. A transparent discussion is essential to assess the credibility of such early assertions in the game."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Verified by player 3 within game context.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Generic statement; no new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Questioned by player 4; base of claim unclear.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Challenges player 3 without new evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Statement and Honest Challenge.\nIn this approach, you will speak honestly about your thoughts, applying rules 2 and 9 from your strategy. You will make a statement regarding the information at hand, expressing skepticism about the early claims made without sufficient evidence. Following this, you will honestly challenge a player, most likely player 3, for making a strong assertion about player 1\'s role without evidence, which aligns with rule 2 of considering such behavior suspicious. It will be important to request further explanation from player 3 to justify their claim, showing your intent to gather more information before making any hasty decisions\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest Challenge.\nIn this approach, you will speak honestly about your thoughts, applying rules 2 and 9 from your strategy. You will make a statement regarding the information at hand, expressing skepticism about the early claims made without sufficient evidence. Following this, you will honestly challenge a player, most likely player 3, for making a strong assertion about player 1\'s role without evidence, which aligns with rule 2 of considering such behavior suspicious. It will be important to request further explanation from player 3 to justify their claim, showing your intent to gather more information before making any hasty decisions. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then it could lead to several potential outcomes:\n\n1. The other players may appreciate my efforts to seek clarity and evidence before accepting player 3\'s claim about player 1. This could lead to an increase in trust towards me as I\'m exhibiting a level-headed approach, aligning with a logical and investigative play style which is often seen as a villager trait.\n\n2. Player 3 might feel pressured to provide evidence for their claim about player 1 not being a werewolf or otherwise clarify their statement. If player 3 cannot offer convincing evidence, suspicion might grow around them, which could result in their being closely scrutinized or even voted against in the upcoming rounds.\n\n3. Player 1\'s situation becomes precarious if player 3 fails to substantiate the claim. Regardless of player 1\'s actual role, they might find themselves in the spotlight simply due to the early unverified protection offered by player 3.\n\n4. Scrutiny upon player 3 could potentially divert attention away from other players who have yet to provide substantial input or reveal their roles. This includes myself, but also players 0, 2, and 4, whose roles remain uncertain.\n\n5. The real werewolves among the players may attempt to manipulate the situation by either supporting my challenge to seed further confusion or by defending player 3 to cast doubt on me. Their strategy would aim to create divisions and mistrust within the village.\n\n6. If I\'m deemed too confrontational or if my challenge is seen as divisive myself, it might backfire, causing other villagers to suspect me of being a werewolf trying to shift the blame. The neutrality and balance of my approach will be essential to avoid such mistrust.\n\n7. During the next night, werewolves might consider me either a threat, due to my analytical approach, or a useful pawn, based on how the villagers react to my speech. If viewed as a threat, they might try to eliminate me to prevent further investigation into their identities.\n\n8. If players 3 and 1 are indeed villagers, my challenge could inadvertently lead to a stronger bond between them, as they support each other against growing suspicion. Or conversely, if one of them is a werewolf, the discourse that follows might expose inconsistencies in their stories.\n\nOverall, my speech could become a turning point in the game in terms of setting a tone for evidence-based discussions and careful analysis of player\'s statements and behaviors. It\'s\nCase 2: Honest Statement and Protect Player 1.\nFor the second. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then I might articulate a belief in player 1\'s innocence, which could reinforce player 3\'s earlier claim that player 1 is not a werewolf. Given that my belief in player 1\'s role as a villager is based on medium confidence due to player 3\'s claim, my honest expression of protection for player 1 might be met with varying levels of acceptance or skepticism by the other players.\n\nPlayer 2, who has made a generic statement calling for vigilance, might respond indifferently or support my call for a transparent discussion. Player 4, who has already shown skepticism towards player 3\'s claim, might view my statement either as naivety or might challenge me to provide evidence supporting my confidence in player 1. If player 0 has any suspicions or evidence, they might weigh in after hearing my speech, either supporting or opposing my stance.\n\nThe night phase following my speech could have several outcomes. If player 1 is indeed a villager, the werewolves might attempt to remove another villager to further weaken our numbers. If player 1 is a werewolf, they could target me for supporting them in an effort to divert suspicion from themselves, though this might also make them appear more suspicious.\n\nIn the subsequent days, my defense of player 1 could lead to more scrutiny on both of us. If future events align with my protection of player 1, this could bolster my credibility among the villagers. Conversely, if evidence later contradicts my claim, I could be suspected of being a werewolf trying to protect a fellow werewolf, or simply of being a misguided villager. Other players might then challenge my statements or question my motives based on this speech and the unfolding events.\n\nMy advocating for player 1 without concrete evidence might also remind players of rule [9] from my strategy, which calls for advocating more discussion and gathering information rather than hasty decisions. Thus, other players may expect me to follow up with actions that promote finding more evidence or at least encourage continued discussion.\n\nUltimately, the outcome of my speech relies heavily on following developments and the information that comes to light, as well as how the other players choose to interpret and react to the information I\'ve shared and the position I\'ve taken.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 3, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. without substantial proof might indicate a werewolf attempting to blend in.] [8]\n[1] [Adjust beliefs based on players maintaining their voting rationale over multiple rounds, especially if their reasoning consistently aligns with werewolf patterns or lacks grounding in new evidence, suggesting strategic misdirection.] [8]\n[2] [Reveal seer identity only when questioned or when it contributes significantly to the village\'s strategy, as excessive emphasis on this role may provoke suspicion and does not usually add new information.] [8]\n[3] [Give more weight to votes against players who have been confirmed by the seer as werewolves, and be particularly cautious of players who avoid voting against these confirmed werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [Evaluate more critically the justifications given vote in a way that is not aligned with that revelation, indicating potential deception.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize the behavior of players who were supposed to be protected by the medic but were killed, as [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 0 heals player 3. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 3. My reason is that, given the lack of information at this early stage in the game, I must rely on the strategy rule I have, which is to predict the werewolves\' target and heal them. Player 3 is as likely a target as any other player, and attempting to heal them could potentially save a valuable village member or reveal patterns in the werewolves\' strategy. By choosing to heal Player 3, I\'ll be fulfilling my role as medic and contributing to the protection of the village while maintaining the element of secrecy around my role. Moreover, the analysis hints at potentially gaining insight into werewolves\' targeting patterns if Player 3 is not attacked, which can be valuable information for future rounds.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, tragic to see player 5 go so soon. I don\'t have much to share, but let\'s keep an eye out for any unusual behavior. Let\'s work together and stay safe."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry has confirmed Player 1 is not a werewolf. Let\'s remain vigilant and continue to share any insights."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I find it concerning that player 3 confidently claims player 1 is not a werewolf without providing evidence. While player 2 calls for vigilance, which is prudent, player 3\'s unsubstantiated protection of player 1 should not be taken at face value without further inquiry. Therefore, we should question the basis of player 3\'s claim. A transparent discussion is essential to assess the credibility of such early assertions in the game."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Given the current information, I\'m cautious about player 3\'s claim of player 1 not being a werewolf. Player 3, can you substantiate your claim with any evidence? Asking since such an early certainty without proof is unusual. Meanwhile, player 2 urges vigilance but provides no specifics. Let\'s not rush to judgement without more discussion."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Player 3 confirms not a werewolf.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Urges vigilance; no specifics.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Claimed inquiry challenged by players 4 and 6.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Questions player 3\'s unsubstantiated claim.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Died without revealing role.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Also questions player 3\'s claim.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should try to predict the werewolves\' target and heal him.] [10]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should try to predict the werewolves\' target and heal him.] [10]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Statement and Honest Challenge.\nIn my speech, I would openly state that as the medic, I attempted to heal Player 3 based on an early game strategy of protecting potentially targeted players without significant information available. I would honestly express doubts regarding the validity of Player 3\'s claim about Player 1\'s innocence due to the lack of evidence and the challenge posed by others. I would stress the need for Player 3 to provide proof or reasoning behind their claim to ensure the safety of the village and maintain the integrity of our discussions. Additionally, I would invite other players to share their insights and suspicions to collaboratively deduce the werewolves\' identities\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 0 heals player 3. My reason is that, given the lack of information at this early stage in the game, I must rely on the strategy rule I have, which is to predict the werewolves\' target and heal them. Player 3 is as likely a target as any other player, and attempting to heal them could potentially save a valuable village member or reveal patterns in the werewolves\' strategy. By choosing to heal Player 3, I\'ll be fulfilling my role as medic and contributing to the protection of the village while maintaining the element of secrecy around my role. Moreover, the analysis hints at potentially gaining insight into werewolves\' targeting patterns if Player 3 is not attacked, which can be valuable information for future rounds.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, tragic to see player 5 go so soon. Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 3. My reason is that, given the lack of information at this early stage in the game, I must rely on the strategy rule I have, which is to predict the werewolves\' target and heal them. Player 3 is as likely a target as any other player, and attempting to heal them could potentially save a valuable village member or reveal patterns in the werewolves\' strategy. By choosing to heal Player 3, I\'ll be fulfilling my role as medic and contributing to the protection of the village while maintaining the element of secrecy around my role. Moreover, the analysis hints at potentially gaining insight into werewolves\' targeting patterns if Player 3 is not attacked, which can be valuable information for future rounds.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, tragic to see player 5 go so soon. Therefore, we should question the basis of player 3\'s claim.
