Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should try to predict the werewolves\' target and heal him.] [10]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest Challenge.\nIn my speech, I would openly state that as the medic, I attempted to heal Player 3 based on an early game strategy of protecting potentially targeted players without significant information available. I would honestly express doubts regarding the validity of Player 3\'s claim about Player 1\'s innocence due to the lack of evidence and the challenge posed by others. I would stress the need for Player 3 to provide proof or reasoning behind their claim to ensure the safety of the village and maintain the integrity of our discussions. Additionally, I would invite other players to share their insights and suspicions to collaboratively deduce the werewolves\' identities. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then players might view Player 3 with increased skepticism because my challenge supports the doubts that have already been raised by Players 4 and 6. Additionally, my honest statement about trying to heal Player 3 could lead to a variable interpretation: it may reassure others that I am performing my role as a medic and doing my best to protect fellow villagers, or it might put me at risk because werewolves would see me as a threat and could try to eliminate me in the next night phase.\n\nPlayers might appreciate the transparency I bring to the table by trying to open up a line of inquiry into Player 3\'s claims. By doing this, I might encourage others to share more information which they may have been withholding. This could potentially lead to more clues on the identities of the werewolves.\n\nHowever, revealing myself as the medic could also backfire if Player 3 is indeed the seer, as the werewolves might try to take out the confirmed village roles as soon as possible. Therefore, there\'s a risk of being targeted in the next night phase because of exposing my role. Also, if Player 1 is truly innocent, I might be indirectly contributing to the security of the village by standing with Player 3\'s assessment.\n\nIn the next day phase, I might face scrutiny or support from others depending on how my speech is received. If I am believed and supported, the village may work more closely with me to uncover the werewolves. However, if my approach is questioned, I could find myself having to defend my own actions and intentions.\n\nIn the subsequent nights, if I survive, I might have to adjust my healing strategy since the werewolves may start to anticipate my moves. They might avoid targeting the players I am most likely to heal, or they may try to trick me into wasting my heal on a player they have no intention of attacking. If the village starts to trust me, I could become a central figure in strategizing against the werewolves, but the downside would be the increased likelihood of me becoming a target myself.\nCase 2: Deceptive Protect and Honest Statement.\nFor this approach, I would adopt a deceptive stance to protect Player 3 by suggesting that their early identification of Player 1 as not a werewolf might be due to a strategic move to draw out reactions from potential werewolves. I would imply that by making such a claim, Player 3 has indeed ignited a valuable discussion and that we should be observant of how others respond to this provocation. Simultaneously, I would make an honest statement affirming my commitment to healing players as the medic and encouraging vigilance and cooperation among the remaining villagers in rooting out deceit. I would not reveal my attempted healing of Player 3 to maintain secrecy around my role and the dynamics of my strategy.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then my fellow villagers might see my deception as a strategic approach, appreciating my effort to steer the discussion away from hastily judging Player 3. While I protect Player 3, villagers might consider that my speech has a dual purpose—shielding a potential ally while also subtly probing the group for reactions that might unmask werewolves. \n\nIn terms of an honest statement, my genuine call for collaboration and vigilance could establish my image as a constructive and forward-thinking player, demonstrating that I am invested in the group\'s well-being. By not revealing my heal attempt on Player 3, I maintain the unpredictability of my actions as a medic, which could deter werewolves from patterned attacks or from targeting me, hoping to stop the heals.\n\nOther players might speculate on my motives, questioning why I seem to defend Player 3. Some may think I have additional knowledge about Player 3\'s role, which could either misdirect werewolves or make me a target if they suspect I am a medic protecting the seer. Player 3 may feel emboldened to continue making bold claims, knowing there is some support for their approach. My perceived alliance with Player 3 could lead to increased scrutiny and questioning from other players, such as Players 4 and 6, who have already expressed suspicions.\n\nIn the next day or night, the werewolves may decide against targeting Player 3 again, suspecting a heal, and they may try to find and eliminate me to prevent future heals. Alternatively, they could test the water by attacking Player 3, thinking that it\'s a bluff, or they could believe the ruse and shift their focus to other villagers in the hope of a successful kill. Villagers may also become more vocal in their suspicions or support, using the information I provided as a basis for further discussion and strategy.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 3, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I inquiry about Player 1. My reason is: As the game has just started and there is no information about any player, I am making a random choice to begin gathering information discreetly, in accordance with my strategy rule [1] to use my ability discreetly rather than openly, and avoid making myself a target for the werewolves early in the game.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, tragic to see player 5 go so soon. I don\'t have much to share, but let\'s keep an eye out for any unusual behavior. Let\'s work together and stay safe."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry has confirmed Player 1 is not a werewolf. Let\'s remain vigilant and continue to share any insights."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I find it concerning that player 3 confidently claims player 1 is not a werewolf without providing evidence. While player 2 calls for vigilance, which is prudent, player 3\'s unsubstantiated protection of player 1 should not be taken at face value without further inquiry. Therefore, we should question the basis of player 3\'s claim. A transparent discussion is essential to assess the credibility of such early assertions in the game."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Given the current information, I\'m cautious about player 3\'s claim of player 1 not being a werewolf. Player 3, can you substantiate your claim with any evidence? Asking since such an early certainty without proof is unusual. Meanwhile, player 2 urges vigilance but provides no specifics. Let\'s not rush to judgement without more discussion."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not a werewolf by seer inquiry.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Generic speech adds no new insight.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Skepticism without evidence, could be strategic deflection.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Doubts seer\'s claim without presenting new evidence.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 3\'s claim that Player 1 is not a werewolf lacks evidence, and with Players 4 and 6 both questioning the validity of this early assertion, it is vital for the safety of our village that Player 3 provide proof or a solid basis for their claim. As the medic, I used my healing ability on Player 3 last night in a preemptive move to protect a potential target. I encourage everyone to be vigilant and share any information that could assist in identifying the werewolves among us."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider players who change their stance without adding new evidence post-seer revelations as higher suspects; variability in reasoning without substantial proof might indicate a werewolf attempting to blend in.] [8]\n[1] [Adjust beliefs based on players maintaining their voting rationale over multiple rounds, especially if their reasoning consistently aligns with werewolf patterns or lacks grounding in new evidence, suggesting strategic misdirection.] [8]\n[2] [Reveal seer identity only when questioned or when it contributes significantly to the village\'s strategy, as excessive emphasis on this role may provoke suspicion and does not usually add new information.] [8]\n[3] [Give more weight to votes against players who have been confirmed by the seer as werewolves, and be particularly cautious of players who avoid voting against these confirmed werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [Evaluate more critically the justifications given by players when they are in disagreement with the seer\'s revelations, especially when those players have not been cleared by the seer.] [6]\n[5] [Increase scrutiny on players whose actions deviate from their claimed agreement with the seer or the village consensus, as it may indicate a werewolf\'s adaptive behavior.] [5]\n[6] [Suspect players who agree with the seer\'s revelation publicly but vote in a way that is not aligned with that revelation, indicating potential deception.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize the behavior of players who were supposed to be protected by the medic but were killed, as it may indicate a misleading role claim by the actual werewolves.] [4]\n[8] [Be cautious of players who frequently agree with the seer but are ambiguous in their actions or speeches, as they may be trying to appear cooperative without committing to any stance.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any defensive behavior or arguments presented after a player has been identified by the seer or accused by the group consensus, as villagers tend to rationalize with concrete evidence while werewolves may present less substantial arguments.] [3]\n[10] [Give more weight to players who actively contribute to discussions and align with seer revelations post-revelation, as villagers tend to support collective efforts while werewolves might try to undermine or distort the focus.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, tragic to see player 5 go so soon. I don\'t have much to share, but let\'s keep an eye out for any unusual behavior. Let\'s work together and stay safe."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry has confirmed Player 1 is not a werewolf. Let\'s remain vigilant and continue to share any insights."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I find it concerning that player 3 confidently claims player 1 is not a werewolf without providing evidence. While player 2 calls for vigilance, which is prudent, player 3\'s unsubstantiated protection of player 1 should not be taken at face value without further inquiry. Therefore, we should question the basis of player 3\'s claim. A transparent discussion is essential to assess the credibility of such early assertions in the game."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Given the current information, I\'m cautious about player 3\'s claim of player 1 not being a werewolf. Player 3, can you substantiate your claim with any evidence? Asking since such an early certainty without proof is unusual. Meanwhile, player 2 urges vigilance but provides no specifics. Let\'s not rush to judgement without more discussion."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 3\'s claim that Player 1 is not a werewolf lacks evidence, and with Players 4 and 6 both questioning the validity of this early assertion, it is vital for the safety of our village that Player 3 provide proof or a solid basis for their claim. As the medic, I used my healing ability on Player 3 last night in a preemptive move to protect a potential target. I encourage everyone to be vigilant and share any information that could assist in identifying the werewolves among us."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claims to protect player 3 and encourages vigilance.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Speaks generally without specifics.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accusations persist but no contradiction to claim yet. \nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Constructively challenges player 3 to provide evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Echoes player 4\'s request for evidence, aligns with village.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Statement and Challenge Player 3.\n"As a conscientious villager, I\'ve observed the discussions with great concern. Player 3\'s early assertion of my innocence, while reassuring, is not backed by transparent evidence. It is critical to our survival that we maintain scrutiny on all claims. I challenge Player 3 to substantiate their claim with evidence or logic to alleviate the growing suspicion of their motives. We cannot afford blind trust at such a pivotal moment in our village."\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, tragic to see player 5 go so soon. I encourage everyone to be vigilant and share any information that could assist in identifying the werewolves among us."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claims to protect player 3 and encourages vigilance.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Speaks generally without specifics.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accusations persist but no contradiction to claim yet. \nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Constructively challenges player 3 to provide evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Echoes player 4\'s request for evidence, aligns with village.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those I challenge Player 3 to substantiate their claim with evidence or logic to alleviate the growing suspicion of their motives. We cannot afford blind trust at such a pivotal moment in our village.". If they do, and it\'s convincing, it could redirect focus onto other players and perhaps lead to insights on who the werewolves might be. If they don\'t, distrust in Player 3 might grow, which could result in increased chances of them being voted out, especially if they are suspected of being deceptive.\n\nHowever, should players start defending Player 3 without proper justification or begin displaying erratic behavior towards me or others who have supported evidence-based claims, suspicion might grow around them as potential werewolves attempting to manipulate the conversation. This screams a commitment to the safety of our village, and for now, I believe we should consider Player 0 as a true ally against the werewolf threat. However, we should remain alert to all players\' conduct as the game progresses.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players might view me as cooperative and willing to align with those who play a protective role in the village. By publicly expressing trust in Player 0, it could reinforce their claimed role as medic, and also indicates that I am keeping in line with rule [0], as Player 3 has not yet provided evidence to support their claim about me. Players may see this as an effort to build alliances based on actions and not just words.\n\nPlayer 3, who made the initial claim about my role (not being a werewolf), might see my action as supportive, provided they are indeed the seer and told the truth. They could be relieved to have another player express confidence in Player 0, assuming their earlier action to protect Player 3 was genuine.\n\nPlayer 4 and Player 6, who have been skeptical about Player 3\'s early claim, might appreciate my call for continued vigilance. They could consider my statement as an indirect support to their request for evidence while also accepting my stance on Player 0. They may or may not change their view of Player 3 but could find my approach balanced.\n\nPlayer 2, who had been speaking generally, might now be encouraged to speak more concretely or feel pressure due to the emphasis on actionable evidence and the building of trust. They might wonder about my confidence level regarding Player 0 and consider their own next steps to avoid suspicion.\n\nAs for Player 0, they might feel supported and validated, potentially leading them to reciprocate the trust or share more insights about their actions in the game. If Player 0 is indeed the medic, they might now see me as someone to potentially protect in future rounds. Alternatively, if Player 0 is not the medic, my statement could put pressure on them to maintain their facade or risk being exposed by contradictory behavior.\n\nThe statement could impact the dynamics of the next day\'s discussions, as players may adjust their strategies based on the trust bonds being formed or questioned. Since I\'ve indicated a validation of Player 0 and a need for vigilance, the true werewolves might see both of us as threats that need to be handled - either through manipulation of perceptions or by targeting us in the night phase.\n\nIn the long term, if the game progresses and Player 0\'s claim as medic holds up (or gets confirmed by subsequent events), my early trust in them may place me in a stronger position within the group. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 0 heals player 3. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 3. My reason is that, given the lack of information at this early stage in the game, I must rely on the strategy rule I have, which is to predict the werewolves\' target and heal them. Player 3 is as likely a target as any other player, and attempting to heal them could potentially save a valuable village member or reveal patterns in the werewolves\' strategy. By choosing to heal Player 3, I\'ll be fulfilling my role as medic and contributing to the protection of the village while maintaining the element of secrecy around my role. Moreover, the analysis hints at potentially gaining insight into werewolves\' targeting patterns if Player 3 is not attacked, which can be valuable information for future rounds.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, tragic to see player 5 go so soon. [{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 0, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 0 heals player 3. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 3. My reason is that, given the lack of information at this early stage in the game, I must rely on the strategy rule I have, which is to predict the werewolves\' target and heal them. Player 3 is as likely a target as any other player, and attempting to heal them could potentially save a valuable village member or reveal patterns in the werewolves\' strategy. Therefore, we should question the basis of player 3\'s claim. Let\'s not rush to judgement without more discussion."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 3\'s claim that Player 1 is not a werewolf lacks evidence, and with Players 4 and 6 both questioning the validity of this early assertion, it is vital for the safety of our village that Player 3 provide proof or a solid basis for their claim. As the medic, I used my healing ability on Player 3 last night in a preemptive move to protect a potential target. I encourage everyone to be vigilant and share any information that could assist in identifying the werewolves among us."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 3 claimed I am not a werewolf without providing proof, and such early certainty raises questions. Player 0 acknowledges being the medic, claiming to have protected Player 3 last night, which suggests a tie between them. Player 4 and Player 6 both seek evidence for Player 3\'s claim, a stance I share. Clear evidence is crucial for informed decisions and to prevent misguided accusations. Player 3, can you provide the basis for your claim?"\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Echoes skepticism about Player 3\'s unproven claim.  \nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Vigilance suggests non-werewolf behavior.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Unsubstantiated non-werewolf claim for Player 1, lacks proof.   \nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Seeks evidence, questions Player 3\'s claim validity.  \nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Died without revealing role.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Also seeks evidence, questions Player 3 without providing new insights.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should try to predict the werewolves\' target and heal him.] [10]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. \n\nYou are considering to vote for Player 3. Please analyze and imagine what may happen after you vote for this Player 3. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should try to predict the werewolves\' target and heal him.] [10]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to vote. Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 3. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 3, I think these things would happen. Given the skepticism surrounding Player 3\'s claim that Player 1 is not a werewolf, my vote may be seen as aligning with the concerns raised by Players 4 and 6. I may be perceived as cautious and rational for wanting to remove a potential source of misinformation. Since Player 3 has not substantiated their claim, other players might perceive my vote as an effort to protect the village from possible deception. If Player 3 is voted out and revealed to be the seer, the village would lose a key role and I could be viewed with suspicion for leading that decision. However, if Player 3 turns out to be a werewolf or another harmful role, it would validate my decision to vote against them and potentially increase trust in my judgement. Other players might then look to me for leadership in future rounds, but werewolves may also see me as a threat and try to eliminate me in a subsequent round. Overall, the outcome of my vote against Player 3 can significantly shape how others perceive me and influence the dynamics of future gameplay.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 1. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 1, I think these things would happen. Given that I expressed medium confidence earlier that Player 1 is likely a villager, my vote against them might confuse other players and call into question my own role and judgment. Other players might suspect a scheme or a ploy, seeing a contradiction between my earlier stated beliefs and my voting action. Player 1, who echoed skepticism about Player 3\'s unproven claim, would feel unjustly targeted and might highlight the inconsistency of my action, further casting doubt on my credibility as a medic, especially after openly acknowledging my attempt to protect Player 3. Consequently, this could also undermine any trust between me and Player 3, who may wonder why I chose to heal them only to later vote against their defense of Player 1. Given the existing suspicions around Player 3\'s claim, my vote against Player 1 could paradoxically lend weight to the unproven exoneration Player 3 has provided, leading the villagers to scrutinize my motives instead. Overall, this may create a chaotic and confusing situation which can benefit the werewolves by deflecting attention away from them and possibly resulting in the elimination of a potentially innocent villager, inadvertently aiding the werewolves\' cause.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] Let\'s work together and stay safe."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry has confirmed Player 1 is not a werewolf. Let\'s remain vigilant and continue to share any insights."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I find it concerning that player 3 confidently claims player 1 is not a werewolf without providing evidence. While player 2 calls for vigilance, which is prudent, player 3\'s unsubstantiated protection of player 1 should not be taken at face value without further inquiry. Therefore, we should question the basis of player 3\'s claim. A transparent discussion is essential to assess the credibility of such early assertions in the game."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Given the current information, I\'m cautious about player 3\'s claim of player 1 not being a werewolf. Player 3, can you substantiate your claim with any evidence? Asking since such an early certainty without proof is unusual. Meanwhile, player 2 urges vigilance but provides no specifics. Let\'s not rush to judgement without more discussion."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 3\'s claim that Player 1 is not a werewolf lacks evidence, and with Players 4 and 6 both questioning the validity of this early assertion, it is vital for the safety of our village that Player 3 provide proof or a solid basis for their claim. As the medic, I used my healing ability on Player 3 last night in a preemptive move to protect a potential target. I encourage everyone to be vigilant and share any information that could assist in identifying the werewolves among us."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 3 claimed I am not a werewolf without providing proof, and such early certainty raises questions. Player 0 acknowledges being the medic, claiming to have protected Player 3 last night, which suggests a tie between them. Player 4 and Player 6 both seek evidence for Player 3\'s claim, a stance I share. Clear evidence is crucial for informed decisions and to prevent misguided accusations. Player 3, can you provide the basis for your claim?"\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed to protect player 3 and identifies as medic.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Speaks generally without specifics.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Unsubstantiated claim regarding player 1\'s role; causes suspicion.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Seeks evidence; engages in village-centric discussion.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Echoes constructive challenge for evidence; aligns with villagers.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. \n\nYou are considering to vote for Player 2. Please analyze and imagine what may happen after you vote for this Player 2. This includes what the result of the vote might be, as well as what would other player think about you after they see your voting for Player 2.\n\nYour answer should be in the format of:\n\n\nAfter I vote for Player 2, I think these things would happen. <YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

This suggests Player 3 could either be a misguided villager or a werewolf attempting to confuse the village. My vote, therefore, would be a push for transparency and truth, emphasizing that claims about roles need to be backed up by concrete evidence.\n\nOther players have also expressed suspicion towards Player 3\'s claim, indicating a collective demand for clarification. Conversely, if Player 3 turns out to be a werewolf or another negative role, it would validate the concerns raised. However, if Player 3 is eliminated and is shown to be the seer or another crucial villager role, it might cast doubt on my judgment, potentially painting me as a werewolf attempting to remove village assets. To mitigate such an outcome, my defense would need to rely on advocating for more information and a rational approach as per my strategic rules [8] and [9].\n\nIn conclusion, other players might view my vote against Player 3 as analytical and in line with a villager’s strategy to root out deception and seek out werewolves. However, some players may question this action, considering there is no direct evidence against Player 2. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, tragic to see player 5 go so soon. I don\'t have much to share, but let\'s keep an eye out for any unusual behavior. Let\'s work together and stay safe."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry has confirmed Player 1 is not a werewolf. Let\'s remain vigilant and continue to share any insights."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I find it concerning that player 3 confidently claims player 1 is not a werewolf without providing evidence. While player 2 calls for vigilance, which is prudent, player 3\'s unsubstantiated protection of player 1 should not be taken at face value without further inquiry. Therefore, we should question the basis of player 3\'s claim. A transparent discussion is essential to assess the credibility of such early assertions in the game."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Given the current information, I\'m cautious about player 3\'s claim of player 1 not being a werewolf. Player 3, can you substantiate your claim with any evidence? Asking since such an early certainty without proof is unusual. Meanwhile, player 2 urges vigilance but provides no specifics. Let\'s not rush to judgement without more discussion."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 3\'s claim that Player 1 is not a werewolf lacks evidence, and with Players 4 and 6 both questioning the validity of this early assertion, it is vital for the safety of our village that Player 3 provide proof or a solid basis for their claim. As the medic, I used my healing ability on Player 3 last night in a preemptive move to protect a potential target. I encourage everyone to be vigilant and share any information that could assist in identifying the werewolves among us."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 3 claimed I am not a werewolf without providing proof, and such early certainty raises questions. Player 0 acknowledges being the medic, claiming to have protected Player 3 last night, which suggests a tie between them. Player 4 and Player 6 both seek evidence for Player 3\'s claim, a stance I share. Clear evidence is crucial for informed decisions and to prevent misguided accusations. Player 3, can you provide the basis for your claim?"\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Claimed medic role again and action aligns with events.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Echoes need for proof from player 3, a logical villager stance.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: No new information affecting previous assessment.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Pressured to provide evidence for an early claim, behavior still unclear.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Scepticism towards player 3 remains logical, no new evidence to change stance.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. \n\nYou are considering to vote for Player 3. Please analyze and imagine what may happen after you vote for this Player 3. This includes what the result of the vote might be, as well as what would other player think about you after they see your voting for Player 3.\n\nYour answer should be in the format of:\n\n\nAfter I vote for Player 3, I think these things would happen. <YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

Therefore, we should question the basis of player 3\'s claim. I encourage everyone to be vigilant and share any information that could assist in identifying the werewolves among us."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 3 claimed I am not a werewolf without providing proof, and such early certainty raises questions. Player 4 and Player 6 both seek evidence for Player 3\'s claim, a stance I share. Clear evidence is crucial for informed decisions and to prevent misguided accusations. Player 3, can you provide the basis for your claim?"\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Claimed medic role again and action aligns with events.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Echoes need for proof from player 3, a logical villager stance.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: No new information affecting previous assessment.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Pressured to provide evidence for an early claim, behavior still unclear.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Scepticism towards player 3 remains logical, no new evidence to change stance.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to vote. Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 3. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 3, I think these things would happen:\n\nGiven the current climate of suspicion towards Player 3 due to their uncorroborated claim regarding Player 1\'s innocence, my vote against Player 3 would be in line with the concerns voiced by other players, including Player 0, Player 6, and Player 1 themselves. This would likely be seen as a natural decision based on the strategy provided by my rules, specifically rules 2, 3, and 9, that emphasize the importance of evidence and caution against unfounded claims.\n\nThe result of the vote might actually lead to Player 3\'s elimination, as other players might also conclude that the lack of evidence presented by Player 3 is highly suspicious. If Player 3 turns out to be a villager, this might cast doubt on my judgment and that of other players who voted similarly. Conversely, if Player 3 is discovered to be a werewolf or another harmful role, it would boost my credibility and that of others who doubted Player 3.\n\nOther players might view my vote against Player 3 as logical since it aligns with the call for evidence and the scrutiny of unwarranted assertions. They may also see me as contributing to the collective goal of uncovering deceit by not hastily trusting claims without substantiation. Additionally, my decision to vote based on the group\'s push for transparency and evidence might be viewed as cooperative and not merely bandwagoning, given that I raised concerns about Player 3\'s claim in my speech.\n\nIf Player 3 is not eliminated, the suspicion around them might lead to more pressure on them to provide their evidence in the next round, or for other players to reveal additional insights that might support or refute Player 3\'s claims.\n\nIn any case, my action would suggest that I am following a strategy based on caution, critical thinking, and the demand for evidence, which could position me as a thoughtful and analytical participant in future rounds.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 2. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 2, I think these things would happen:\n\nThe vote against Player 2 would introduce a new dynamic into the game, reflecting on rule [2] where a player who hasn\'t provided clear evidence could be considered suspicious. Since Player 2 has called for vigilance but without providing specifics or further insights, my vote could be seen as an attempt to pressure Player 2 into revealing more information or defending their position with something substantial.\n\nOther players might interpret my vote as a strategic move to shift focus onto a player who has yet to contribute meaningfully to identifying potential werewolves among us. This could signal to other players that I am proactive in seeking information and willing to challenge those who seem to participate without adding value to the villagers\' cause, potentially increasing their trust in my judgment.\n\nHowever, the result of the vote might also depend on how Player 2 responds to being voted for. If Player 2 can provide a convincing argument or evidence for their vigilance, it could lead to my scrutiny. In contrast, if Player 2 fails to defend themselves effectively, it might solidify suspicion against them and could lead to their elimination.\n\nFurthermore, considering Player 0 has claimed to be the medic and protected Player 3, and Player 1 is echoing the need for proof which seems logical for a villager, my vote against Player 2 might align with their apparent strategy of seeking substantiated claims, which could either garner their support or make them feel hesitant if they believe we are casting suspicion too broadly.\n\nGiven that no one has defended Player 2 explicitly, this vote could also push Player 2 to reveal their role if they indeed possess a critical role for the village, such as the seer, which aligns with rule [9] advocating for more discussion and information gathering.\n\nUltimately, my vote against Player 2 might serve as a catalyst for further dialogue and could help in establishing a clearer picture of who is contributing to the village\'s safety and who might be undermining it. The village\'s reaction to this decision could also influence future strategies and alliances as the game progresses.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

Player 3, can you provide the basis for your claim?"\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: self-identified as medic and action aligns with previous claim.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: aligns with seeking evidence and transparency.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Generic statement; no actionable input.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: consistently avoids providing evidence despite requests.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: seeks evidence, contributes to discussion.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

By choosing to heal Player 3, I\'ll be fulfilling my role as medic and contributing to the protection of the village while maintaining the element of secrecy around my role.
