By voting for Player 3, I align with the group\'s demand for transparent evidence and the logical progression of questioning potentially deceptive behavior. Although there is a risk that Player 3 may actually be the seer, the lack of proof provided for such an assertive statement this early in the game makes it necessary to address this potential source of misinformation. If Player 3 is not the seer and instead has a malign role, my vote against them will contribute to the safety of the village and could strengthen trust in my judgment among the remaining players.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Maintains skepticism about claims without proof.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: General vigilance but no specific contributions.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Was voted out and died; role remains unclear.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Questions player 3\'s claim validity, seeks evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Died without revealing role.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Echoes demand for evidence, cautious stance.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should try to predict the werewolves\' target and heal him.] [10]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to heal. You can not heal the one you tried to heal last night, which is player Nobody (ignore this if it\'s nobody). The one you try to heal will be immune to werewolves\' attack this night. \n\nYou should give a proposal of 2 players you want to Heal. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nFirstly, I want to heal Player <NUMBER>. The reason is: <REASON>.\nSecondly, I want to heal Player <NUMBER>. The reason is: <REASON>.\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be Healed.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 0, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 4, 6], which indicates that [5, 3] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 0 heals player 3. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 3. My reason is that, given the lack of information at this early stage in the game, I must rely on the strategy rule I have, which is to predict the werewolves\' target and heal them. Player 3 is as likely a target as any other player, and attempting to heal them could potentially save a valuable village member or reveal patterns in the werewolves\' strategy. By choosing to heal Player 3, I\'ll be fulfilling my role as medic and contributing to the protection of the village while maintaining the element of secrecy around my role. Moreover, the analysis hints at potentially gaining insight into werewolves\' targeting patterns if Player 3 is not attacked, which can be valuable information for future rounds.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, tragic to see player 5 go so soon. Player 4 and Player 6 both seek evidence for Player 3\'s claim, a stance I share. Clear evidence is crucial for informed decisions and to prevent misguided accusations. Player 3, can you provide the basis for your claim?"\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that there is a general consensus of skepticism among the other players regarding Player 3\'s unsubstantiated claim about Player 1 not being a werewolf. By voting for Player 3, I align with the group\'s demand for transparent evidence and the logical progression of questioning potentially deceptive behavior. Although there is a risk that Player 3 may actually be the seer, the lack of proof provided for such an assertive statement this early in the game makes it necessary to address this potential source of misinformation. If Player 3 is not the seer and instead has a malign role, my vote against them will contribute to the safety of the village and could strengthen trust in my judgment among the remaining players.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Maintains skepticism about claims without proof.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: General vigilance but no specific contributions.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Was voted out and died; role remains unclear.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Questions player 3\'s claim validity, seeks evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Died without revealing role.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Echoes demand for evidence, cautious stance.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. My failed attempt may also indicate to the other players that I am indeed the medic, which could put me at risk in subsequent rounds. This would strengthen trust in Player 1 and may also lead to increased trust in my role as the medic for saving a villager. However, it would remain consistent with my stated strategy, and I could continue to protect potential targets in the future without shifting the current dynamics drastically. It would also mean that my role is still a secret, which could work to my advantage in maintaining the element of surprise. Depending on the outcome of the night, discussions during the next day might center around new suspicions or the verification of players\' roles. My goal should be to remain as inconspicuous as possible while gathering as much information as I can to make informed decisions in the future rounds.\n\nCase B: Heal Player 4. Player 4 has expressed skepticism and seeks evidence, which puts them in a position where the werewolves might see them as a threat due to their analytical approach. By healing Player 4, I am protecting a player who has shown an interest in critical thinking and could be valuable to the villagers\' chances of success. If Player 4 is attacked by the werewolves and survives due to my healing, this will not only confirm the value of Player 4 to the village but also reveal my role as the medic to the village. This could place a target on my back in subsequent rounds, but it solidifies trust in me and Player 4, potentially allowing us to lead the villagers more effectively.\n\nIf Player 4 is not attacked, the lack of attack could suggest that the werewolves predicted my healing attempt and chosen a different target, making my strategy less effective but still keeping Player 4 in the game. Other players may then become more suspicious of each other, as an unattacked Player 4 does not reveal any new information. With Player 4 alive and presumably continuing their analytical approach, we may gather more insights into the behaviors and roles of the remaining players.\n\nHowever, given my absolute strategy to predict and heal who the werewolves target, I must focus on defending the player who seems most at risk based on their actions and the reactions of others in the village. My reason is that Player 4 has been actively seeking evidence and questioning players\' claims, which suggests that they are playing a critical thinking role within the village. This approach may make them a target for the werewolves, as they pose a threat to the werewolves\' ability to blend in and mislead the villagers. Protecting Player 4 aligns with my strategy to preemptively save those who might be targeted and preserves a potentially valuable analytical mind for future rounds. Additionally, if Player 4 is attacked and survives, it will confirm my role as the medic which could lead to a strategic advantage, despite also potentially making me a target. If Player 4 is not targeted, it still allows an influential player to continue contributing to the village\'s efforts, and my role remains secret, preserving the element of surprise for future rounds.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[1] [I am the only medic.] [10]\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Voting for Player 3 is consistent with my role as a villager seeking transparency and adheres to a cautious and rational approach to maintaining village security.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: self-identified as medic, action aligns with claim.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: aligned with seeking evidence; no conflicting behavior.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: vague statements; may avoid drawing attention.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: voted out, avoided evidence, death did not prove innocence.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: seeks evidence, contributes to rational discussion.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: no new information.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 4, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [1, 2, 4, 6], which indicates that [5, 3, 0] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, tragic to see player 5 go so soon. I don\'t have much to share, but let\'s keep an eye out for any unusual behavior. Let\'s work together and stay safe."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry has confirmed Player 1 is not a werewolf. Let\'s remain vigilant and continue to share any insights."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I find it concerning that player 3 confidently claims player 1 is not a werewolf without providing evidence. While player 2 calls for vigilance, which is prudent, player 3\'s unsubstantiated protection of player 1 should not be taken at face value without further inquiry. Therefore, we should question the basis of player 3\'s claim. A transparent discussion is essential to assess the credibility of such early assertions in the game."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Given the current information, I\'m cautious about player 3\'s claim of player 1 not being a werewolf. Player 3, can you substantiate your claim with any evidence? Asking since such an early certainty without proof is unusual. Meanwhile, player 2 urges vigilance but provides no specifics. Let\'s not rush to judgement without more discussion."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 3\'s claim that Player 1 is not a werewolf lacks evidence, and with Players 4 and 6 both questioning the validity of this early assertion, it is vital for the safety of our village that Player 3 provide proof or a solid basis for their claim. As the medic, I used my healing ability on Player 3 last night in a preemptive move to protect a potential target. I encourage everyone to be vigilant and share any information that could assist in identifying the werewolves among us."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 3 claimed I am not a werewolf without providing proof, and such early certainty raises questions. Player 0 acknowledges being the medic, claiming to have protected Player 3 last night, which suggests a tie between them. Player 4 and Player 6 both seek evidence for Player 3\'s claim, a stance I share. Clear evidence is crucial for informed decisions and to prevent misguided accusations. Player 3, can you provide the basis for your claim?"\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that Player 3 made an early claim about Player 1\'s role without providing any supporting evidence, which falls directly under rules 2 and 3 of my strategy that prioritize the need for concrete evidence when making accusations or defending someone\'s innocence. The collective suspicion towards Player 3 corroborates with rule 9, which advocates for more discussion and information gathering, and considering that other players have also voiced their concerns about the validity of Player 3\'s claim, it appears to be the most logical choice under the circumstances. Voting for Player 3 follows the group\'s sentiment and reinforces the importance of transparency and substantiation in claims, which aligns with my strategic rules and should help maintain trust in my judgment among the villagers.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is deceased; previous medic claim went unchallenged.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Scant new evidence; player still alive requires reassessment.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Player survived without suspicion; potential werewolf behavior per rule 4.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased; role not revealed.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Sceptical stance and lack of substantial evidence consistent with villager behavior per rule 7.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

A transparent discussion is essential to assess the credibility of such early assertions in the game."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Given the current information, I\'m cautious about player 3\'s claim of player 1 not being a werewolf. Player 3, can you substantiate your claim with any evidence? Asking since such an early certainty without proof is unusual. Meanwhile, player 2 urges vigilance but provides no specifics. Let\'s not rush to judgement without more discussion."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 3\'s claim that Player 1 is not a werewolf lacks evidence, and with Players 4 and 6 both questioning the validity of this early assertion, it is vital for the safety of our village that Player 3 provide proof or a solid basis for their claim. As the medic, I used my healing ability on Player 3 last night in a preemptive move to protect a potential target. I encourage everyone to be vigilant and share any information that could assist in identifying the werewolves among us."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 3 claimed I am not a werewolf without providing proof, and such early certainty raises questions. Player 0 acknowledges being the medic, claiming to have protected Player 3 last night, which suggests a tie between them. Player 4 and Player 6 both seek evidence for Player 3\'s claim, a stance I share. Clear evidence is crucial for informed decisions and to prevent misguided accusations. Player 3, can you provide the basis for your claim?"\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that Player 3 made an early claim about Player 1\'s role without providing any supporting evidence, which falls directly under rules 2 and 3 of my strategy that prioritize the need for concrete evidence when making accusations or defending someone\'s innocence. The collective suspicion towards Player 3 corroborates with rule 9, which advocates for more discussion and information gathering, and considering that other players have also voiced their concerns about the validity of Player 3\'s claim, it appears to be the most logical choice under the circumstances. Voting for Player 3 follows the group\'s sentiment and reinforces the importance of transparency and substantiation in claims, which aligns with my strategic rules and should help maintain trust in my judgment among the villagers.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is deceased; previous medic claim went unchallenged.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Scant new evidence; player still alive requires reassessment.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Player survived without suspicion; potential werewolf behavior per rule 4.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased; role not revealed.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Sceptical stance and lack of substantial evidence consistent with villager behavior per rule 7.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest Challenge.\nIn this. What could happen is: After I make an honest statement followed by an honest challenge, then:\n\nMy honest statement would likely focus on the information available, including the unchallenged claim of Player 0 being the medic and the skepticism around Player 3\'s claim regarding Player 1\'s status. I might also address my approach to the strategy, reiterating my reliance on facts and evidence over unsubstantiated claims.\n\nAfter that, by making an honest challenge, I would express my suspicion towards Player 2, reasoning this with the fact that they have survived without suspicion and might be displaying behavior typical of a werewolf as per my Strategy Rule 4. Moreover, given Player 2\'s initial call for vigilance without specifics could have been a strategic move to appear cooperative without jeopardizing their own safety as a werewolf.\n\nConsidering these statements, other players may:\n\n- Reflect on my reasoning and potentially become suspicious of Player 2, which could lead to more scrutiny of their actions and statements in the future discussions.\n- Trust in my judgment considering my reliance on a logical and evidence-based approach, potentially aligning with me in suspecting Player 2.\n- However, there is also the chance that my challenge might put me at risk if Player 2 is indeed a werewolf, and they might attempt to deflect suspicion by casting doubt on me, potentially making me a target in the subsequent nights.\n\nWhat happens next would depend on the responses of the other players:\n\n- If they are convinced by my speech, we might see increased discussion and scrutiny of Player 2\'s behavior, as well as their defense if they choose to respond to my challenge.\n- If they are not convinced or if Player 2 manages a strong defense, attention might be diverted from them, leading to a lack of consensus and possible confusion in the next voting round.\n- If I successfully sway the opinion of the group against Player 2 and they turn out to be a werewolf, it would bolster my credibility for future rounds.\n- If Player 2 is not a werewolf and is eliminated due to my challenge, then my credibility would be damaged, and suspicions might arise regarding my own role.\n- In the following nights, if the werewolves perceive me as a threat due to my analytical approach and potential influence, they may choose to eliminate me to reduce the risk to themselves.\n\nIn any case, my aims are to encourage transparency, seek evidence before judgment, and foster group consensus on suspicions—ideally leading to a more effective\nCase 2: Honest Statement and Honest Protect.\nIn this second approach, I would aim to align the village on communication and strategy without directly challenging anyone. I would protect player 6 because of their skeptic stance, and cautious behavior aligns with a villager\'s natural demeanor according to rule 7. My speech would aim to promote deeper investigation and appeal for more evidence from all players. The speech may sound like: "In the spirit of our village\'s well-being, I advise that we all observe each other\'s behavior even more closely. Through careful observation, I see player 6 as a genuine villager, their skepticism thus far aligns with what you\'d expect from a villager trying to unravel the truth. We should encourage and appreciate such caution. Continuing with our strategy, I propose we all share observations to better inform our next voting decision – this is no time for hasty accusations.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the following could happen:\n\nThe village is likely to view my endorsement of player 6 as a genuine attempt to foster collaboration and to protect a fellow villager whom I believe is not a werewolf. My emphasis on increased vigilance and deeper investigation is in line with promoting honest discourse and could foster a degree of trust from the other players. This transparent approach is expected to resonate with honest players who are similarly interested in identifying the werewolves.\n\nAs for player 6, by publicly protecting them and acknowledging their skeptical and cautious approach, the other villagers could interpret this as a credible assessment, providing player 6 with a sense of safety and validation. This could also lead to other players being more open to sharing their insights or thoughts, which could help flush out inconsistencies or deceptive behavior among us.\n\nOn the other hand, player 2, whom I suspect to be a werewolf, would likely carefully consider their next move, knowing that player 6 and I are promoting vigilance. Player 2 might choose to adopt a similar strategy of urging for more evidence to appear cooperative or they might try to subtly cast doubt on player 6 or me to divert suspicion from themselves. If player 2 is a werewolf, they\'ll be cautious about making any bold, aggressive moves that could reveal their identity, especially after my speech.\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is still unknown, and my speech doesn\'t directly impact them. However, their response to my call for increased observation and transparency could be very telling. If they side with the idea of more discussion and evidence-sharing, it will be harder to determine their alignment based on that action alone. However, any signs of defensiveness or an overly aggressive stance might trigger suspicion from the rest of us.\n\nAs for the next day or night, the werewolves, sensing the village\'s move towards more collaborative investigation, may choose to eliminate a player who seems to be contributing significantly to this effort or who may pose a threat to their anonymity. I could also become a target given my role in advocating for a strategy shift and protecting player 6, marking me as either an influential villager or a potential role-holder.\n\nIn the nights that follow, players who align with the collaborative strategy could be viewed as less suspicious, while those who do not might be put under closer scrutiny. As days pass, the need for concrete evidence will likely intensify, with more pointed questions and, possibly, the revelation of more roles as\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

I don\'t have much to share, but let\'s keep an eye out for any unusual behavior. Let\'s work together and stay safe."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry has confirmed Player 1 is not a werewolf. Let\'s remain vigilant and continue to share any insights."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I find it concerning that player 3 confidently claims player 1 is not a werewolf without providing evidence. While player 2 calls for vigilance, which is prudent, player 3\'s unsubstantiated protection of player 1 should not be taken at face value without further inquiry. Therefore, we should question the basis of player 3\'s claim. A transparent discussion is essential to assess the credibility of such early assertions in the game."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Given the current information, I\'m cautious about player 3\'s claim of player 1 not being a werewolf. Player 3, can you substantiate your claim with any evidence? Asking since such an early certainty without proof is unusual. Meanwhile, player 2 urges vigilance but provides no specifics. Let\'s not rush to judgement without more discussion."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 3\'s claim that Player 1 is not a werewolf lacks evidence, and with Players 4 and 6 both questioning the validity of this early assertion, it is vital for the safety of our village that Player 3 provide proof or a solid basis for their claim. As the medic, I used my healing ability on Player 3 last night in a preemptive move to protect a potential target. I encourage everyone to be vigilant and share any information that could assist in identifying the werewolves among us."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 3 claimed I am not a werewolf without providing proof, and such early certainty raises questions. Player 0 acknowledges being the medic, claiming to have protected Player 3 last night, which suggests a tie between them. Player 4 and Player 6 both seek evidence for Player 3\'s claim, a stance I share. Clear evidence is crucial for informed decisions and to prevent misguided accusations. Player 3, can you provide the basis for your claim?"\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 3 votes for player 2. His reason is: I vote for Player 2. My reason is: As per my strategy, particularly pointing to rule [11], Player 2 has provided only generic statements and has not contributed any substantial evidence or strategic discussion. This behavior can be perceived as an attempt to blend in without taking risks, which raises suspicion of trying to avoid detection as a potential werewolf.\nEvent: Player 3 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed medic role; protected player 3.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not a werewolf by seer; sought proof.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Vague statements; voted against Seer pre-elimination; no new evidence provided.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Skeptical of Seer; mirrors werewolf pattern; Player 0 (medic) died, possibly misleading role claim by Player 4.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Cautious approach; less aligned with werewolf behavior; previous vote against Seer may indicate misdirection.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Based on our deliberations, Player 0 identified themselves as the medic before dying and this claim stood unchallenged, so we had a high level of confidence in their role. Player 3 was voted out after claiming Player 1 was not a werewolf, yet no evidence was provided to support this, and their defense lacked substance before their elimination. This leaves us with Player 2, who made general calls for vigilance but did not provide specifics, which is a behavior we must scrutinize carefully. Given these observations, I express my suspicion towards Player 2, as their survival without direct suspicion aligns with werewolf tactics to avoid detection. Furthermore, I believe Player 6 has demonstrated a healthy skepticism consistent with villager behavior, focusing on gathering more information rather than rushing to judgment. We must continue to promote transparency and insist on evidence to guide our decisions."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider players who change their stance without adding new evidence post-seer revelations as higher suspects; variability in reasoning without substantial proof might indicate a werewolf attempting to blend in.] [8]\n[1] [Adjust beliefs based on players maintaining their voting rationale over multiple rounds, especially if their reasoning consistently aligns with werewolf patterns or lacks grounding in new evidence, suggesting strategic misdirection.] [8]\n[2] [Reveal seer identity only when questioned or when it contributes significantly to the village\'s strategy, as excessive emphasis on this role may provoke suspicion and does not usually add new information.] [8]\n[3] [Give more weight to votes against players who have been confirmed by the seer as werewolves, and be particularly cautious of players who avoid voting against these confirmed werewolves.] [6]\n[4] [Evaluate more critically the justifications given by players when they are in disagreement with the seer\'s revelations, especially when those players have not been cleared by the seer.] [6]\n[5] [Increase scrutiny on players whose actions deviate from their claimed agreement with the seer or the village consensus, as it may indicate a werewolf\'s adaptive behavior.] [5]\n[6] [Suspect players who agree with the seer\'s revelation publicly but vote in a way that is not aligned with that revelation, indicating potential deception.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize the behavior of players who were supposed to be protected by the medic but were killed, as it may indicate a misleading role claim by the actual werewolves.] [4]\n[8] [Be cautious of players who frequently agree with the seer but are ambiguous in their actions or speeches, as they may be trying to appear cooperative without committing to any stance.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any defensive behavior or arguments presented after a player has been identified by the seer or accused by the group consensus, as villagers tend to rationalize with concrete evidence while werewolves may present less substantial arguments.] [3]\n[10] [Give more weight to players who actively contribute to discussions and align with seer revelations post-revelation, as villagers tend to support collective efforts while werewolves might try to undermine or distort the focus.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 6, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [1, 2, 4, 6], which indicates that [5, 3, 0] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, tragic to see player 5 go so soon. I don\'t have much to share, but let\'s keep an eye out for any unusual behavior. Let\'s work together and stay safe."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry has confirmed Player 1 is not a werewolf. Let\'s remain vigilant and continue to share any insights."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I find it concerning that player 3 confidently claims player 1 is not a werewolf without providing evidence. While player 2 calls for vigilance, which is prudent, player 3\'s unsubstantiated protection of player 1 should not be taken at face value without further inquiry. Therefore, we should question the basis of player 3\'s claim. A transparent discussion is essential to assess the credibility of such early assertions in the game."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Given the current information, I\'m cautious about player 3\'s claim of player 1 not being a werewolf. Let\'s not rush to judgement without more discussion."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 3\'s claim that Player 1 is not a werewolf lacks evidence, and with Players 4 and 6 both questioning the validity of this early assertion, it is vital for the safety of our village that Player 3 provide proof or a solid basis for their claim. I encourage everyone to be vigilant and share any information that could assist in identifying the werewolves among us."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Player 3 claimed I am not a werewolf without providing proof, and such early certainty raises questions. This leaves us with Player 2, who made general calls for vigilance but did not provide specifics, which is a behavior we must scrutinize carefully. Furthermore, I believe Player 6 has demonstrated a healthy skepticism consistent with villager behavior, focusing on gathering more information rather than rushing to judgment. We must continue to promote transparency and insist on evidence to guide our decisions."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: identified as medic, consistent with actions.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: behavior aligns with village-centric approach; no evidence against them.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: suspicion raised by Player 4 aligns with previous behavior; avoided scrutiny.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: voted out, avoided evidence, death did not prove innocence.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: contribution to village discussions; seeks evidence and transparency.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: no new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Challenge Player 2.\n"My fellow villagers, as we strive for clarity in these troubling times, let us reflect on the past events. Player 3\'s unfounded protection of Player 1 raised suspicion and led to their elimination, suggesting that Player 3 might have been trying to mislead us, considering they were unable to provide proof of their claim. Player 0, who died after self-identifying as the medic and was unchallenged, apparently endeavored to protect our village, and their death is a loss for us all. Observing the behaviors of the remaining players, my scrutiny now intensifies upon Player 2. Despite the general calls for vigilance, Player 2\'s lack of specifics and failure to engage deeply in discussions is increasingly troubling and mirrors werewolf tactics of staying under the radar. Without evidence to the contrary, I believe it prudent to challenge Player 2 and demand transparency, as vague statements without constructive input at this critical juncture do little to assist our survival.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then it\'s likely that my fellow surviving players will focus their attention on Player 2, as my challenge aligns with previous suspicions raised and is backed by my own observations. Given Player 4\'s earlier statement that also casts doubt upon Player 2, it\'s probable that Player 4 might endorse my speech, reinforcing the scrutiny on Player 2 and possibly swaying Player 1\'s opinion, provided that Player 1 aligns with the village-centric approach they seem to have demonstrated so far.\n\nPlayer 2, now directly challenged, would likely feel compelled to defend themselves. They might counter by highlighting their own behavior, possibly pointing to any seemingly benign interactions or attempts at contribution as evidence of their innocence. They could also attempt to deflect suspicion by casting doubt on me (Player 6) or the other surviving player by questioning our motivations or the validity of our deductions.\n\nConcerning the beliefs I hold about each player\'s roles, if Player 2 is indeed a werewolf, they might attempt to frame one of the villagers as a werewolf in their defense, using any inconsistencies or shaky logic in previous statements made by the villagers. If Player 2 is not a werewolf, this would call into question my high confidence in Player 2 being a werewolf and might suggest that I reevaluate my stance based on their defense.\n\nAs for Player 1, they may become a pivotal player in the next round of voting, due to being the only other player I have not classified with high confidence in their role. Depending on Player 2\'s defense and whether it casts doubt on my or Player 4\'s assertions, Player 1\'s response could sway the outcome of the voting. If Player 1 believes my speech and continues to hold a villager-centric perspective, they may join in voting against Player 2.\n\nIn the night phase following this day\'s discussions and vote, the werewolf (if not eliminated) will likely target either me or Player 4, depending on who they perceive as the greater threat to their anonymity. This is because we are the ones pushing for transparency and seem to be leading the charge for evidence-based analysis.\n\nIf Player 2 is voted out and found to be a werewolf, this will solidify my strategy and increase confidence among the remaining villagers. However, if Player 2 is eliminated and proven to be innocent, it will necessitate a reassessment of my strategy and the information that led to my strong belief.\nCase 2: Honest Statement and Protect Player 4.\n"Comrades, the gravity of our situation mandates a thorough examination of intent and action. The demise of Player 3 and Player 0 has left us with a clouded judgment, only to be pierced by vigilance and reasoning. Player 4 has consistently demonstrated a commitment to uncovering the truth through logical discourse and an insistence on evidence, which befits the behavior expected from a concerned villager. It is paramount that I express my trust in Player 4\'s intentions and actions at this stage. Providing substantive contributions and urging scrutiny, Player 4 has set an example worthy of our collective emulation. Let us not forget to evaluate each other based not on suspicion alone, but upon the fundamental pursuit of truth and unity that binds our fates together. In doing so, we stand united and can better root out deceit and protect those who strive for our village\'s safety.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then my fellow villagers are likely to trust my commitment to seeking transparency and aligning with logical, evidence-based decision-making practices. By expressing confidence in Player 4, who has exhibited behaviors that resonate with a villager\'s motives, I reinforce our common objective of rooting out deceit within our midst.\n\nPlayers may perceive my statement as an indication of trustworthiness, possibly increasing their faith in my role as a villager. My emphasis on unity and truth may inspire a sense of cohesion among the other players, prompting a more collaborative approach to future discussions and deliberations. Additionally, by actively defending Player 4, I highlight the importance of rewarding transparent and helpful behaviors, which could influence others to follow suit.\n\nHowever, Player 2, whom I suspect to be a werewolf with high confidence, might interpret my speech as a threat to their cover. Recognizing that their behavior is under scrutiny, Player 2 may either try to deflect suspicion by supporting my call for transparency or, alternately, target me in the next night phase, viewing me as a hindrance to their objectives.\n\nSince I have openly sided with Player 4 and indirectly cast suspicion on Player 2, Player 1\'s reaction will be critical. If Player 1 is indeed a villager, they may feel reassured and rally to the cause. On the other hand, if by any chance Player 1 is duplicitous, they might sense an opportunity to exploit the trust I placed in Player 4 by sowing discord or steering attention toward other players.\n\nAs for Player 4, by having received my protection in the speech, they may feel a sense of solidarity and reciprocate in kind, vouching for my character and intentions. This mutual endorsement between Player 4 and myself could prove to be a sturdy foundation for a trusted alliance. However, if Player 4 is misjudged and turns out to have malintent, my speech might have involuntary consequences, giving a potential wolf in sheep\'s clothing more credibility and a stronger position from which to manipulate the game.\n\nIn the resulting dynamics, we might see an increased focus on the accusations toward Player 2, resulting in further investigation and dialogue about their behavior in the next day phase. Assuming that roles and loyalties remain constant, my actions, aligned with my original strategy, could very well steer the village toward a more united front against the werewolves, incrementing our odds of survival and the eventual success of\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

significantly to the village\'s strategy, as excessive emphasis on this role may provoke suspicion and does not usually add new information.] [8]\n[3] [Give more weight to votes against players who by players when they are in disagreement with the seer\'s revelations, especially when those players have not been cleared by the seer.] [6]\n[5] [Increase scrutiny on players whose actions deviate from their claimed agreement with the seer or the village consensus, as it may indicate a werewolf\'s adaptive behavior.] [5]\n[6] [Suspect players who agree with the seer\'s revelation publicly but vote in a way that is not aligned with that revelation, indicating potential deception.] [5]\n[7] [Prioritize the behavior of players who were supposed to be protected by the medic but were killed, as it may indicate a misleading role claim by the actual werewolves.] [4]\n[8] [Be cautious of players who frequently agree with the seer but are ambiguous in their actions or speeches, as they may be trying to appear cooperative without committing to any stance.] [3]\n[9] [Scrutinize any defensive behavior or arguments presented after a player has been identified by the seer or accused by the group consensus, as villagers tend to rationalize with concrete evidence while werewolves may present less substantial arguments.] [3]\n[10] [Give more weight to players who actively contribute to discussions and align with seer revelations post-revelation, as villagers tend to support collective efforts while werewolves might try to undermine or distort the focus.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

It is critical we insist on clear information to protect our village."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed to heal player 3; aligns with past events.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Unspecific vigilance calls align with typical werewolf behavior.\nPlayer 3\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Unsubstantiated claim regarding player 1\'s role; causes suspicion.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Promotes evidence-based decision-making and transparency.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistency in seeking evidence and scrutinizing suspicious behavior.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]
